Under the Treaties of Velasco Zavala was appointed a peace commissioner to accompany Santa Anna to Mexico City, but returned to his home in poor health shortly thereafter. He resigned the vice presidency on October 17, 1836.

Zavala's legislative, executive, ministerial, and diplomatic experience, together with his education and linguistic ability, uniquely qualified him for the role he was to play in the drafting of the constitution of the Republic of Texas.

When he learned that Santa Anna had assumed dictatorial powers in 1834, Zavala denounced his former ally, resigned his post, and eventually went to Texas. Although he first advocated the cause of Mexican Federalism, he soon became an active supporter of the independence movement.

In the 1820s he helped establish a republican government in newly independent Mexico, but was forced into exile in 1830. Zavala returned to Mexico in 1832 and was named to serve as the first minister plenipotentiary of the Mexican legation in Paris.

His support of democratic reforms led to his imprisonment in 1814 in Veracruz, where he gained enough knowledge from reading medical textbooks to qualify him to practice medicine upon his release in 1817. He also taught himself to read English during his imprisonment.
On this day in 1836, Lorenzo de Zavala, the first vice president of the Republic of Texas, died. Zavala was born in 1788 in Mexico. @TxStHistAssoc

(5/5) Your support means everything to me as we build our own movement and community together, too. 
So, thanks for letting me share these memories -- and for everything else you’re doing to help keep us moving forward. I promise, I won’t embarrass you like I embarrassed Jordan!

(4/5) I wonder how many first crushes or single moms and their kids are still skating around the rink these days.
I was so touched when some of those moms reached out after Jordan’s funeral and to still see their names to this day on our campaign supporters’ list.

(3/5) “Mom, don’t acknowledge me. Don’t act like you know me! Just skate on by.” So, I did. I skated right on by as Jordan held hands with his new crush.
Then, I would shout the best, over-the-top “Oh, Jordan! Come skate with Mommy!” act I could without falling over laughing.

(2/5) Our local roller rink became our little, affordable Monday after-school ritual from 4-8 PM.
Pretty soon, I started recognizing other single moms there with their kids. Then, the girls showed up -- or, to be more accurate: Jordan started noticing the girls showing up.

(1/5) I was doing some decluttering at the house this month, and I came across the funniest thing -- two old pairs of roller skates: mine and Jordan’s.
As a single mom, I needed to find affordable ways to keep my high-energy boy busy.

Jobs

I was proud to witness the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act become law and will work to ensure our district and our state can access these critical investments in the years to come.
The investments we are making today build an infrastructure for the next generation, one that funds our road, bridges and highways, but one that also funds our future.
This includes a network for electric vehicle chargers, zero emission school busses and funding to research the next generation of clean energy technology.

The bill is an important step forward in our work to combat climate change. It includes $21 billion to protect our nation’s environment and more than $73 billion to invest in clean energy infrastructure across our county.
The Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act also provides funds for our state to invest $100 million in expanding broadband in rural and underserved areas.

Importantly, California will receive an $84 million investment to help mitigate the impact of future fires, including money for forest management projects and funding so homeowners can better fireproof their homes.

The bill, which I voted to pass earlier this month, provides $25.3 billion for highways, $4.2 billion for bridges, and $9.45 billion for transit projects in California. This important funding will be spent in our district to address our local infrastructure and create jobs.
